ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: and man asks, 'What is wrong with it?',
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: And man enquires: "What has come over it?"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: and man will cry out: “What is the matter with her?”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: the human being will say (in horror), "What is happening to it?"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: And man says, “What has happened to it?”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: And man will say: "What is the matter with it"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: And man says: What has befallen her?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: And man saith: What aileth her?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: when man asks, "What is happening to her?";
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: And man saith: what aileth her?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: and man says, ‘What is the matter with her?’
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: And man cries (distressed): 'What is the matter with her?'-
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: And man will say: "What is the matter with it?"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: and the human asks: "What is the matter with it?"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: And man says, “What is the matter with it?”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: And man says, "What is [wrong] with it?" -
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [99:3] and man, the disbeliever in resurrection, says, ‘What is wrong with it?’ — in denial of that situation.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (And man) i.e. the disbeliever (saith: What aileth her?) He says this in astonishment from the horror he sees
